newsitem.title: UK: Britain clamps down on child sex tour organisers.
newsitem.headline: Britain clamps down on child sex tour organisers.

text.p: A bill making it illegal for Britons to organise paedophile holidays abroad became law on Tuesday and offenders could face life imprisonment.
The bill makes it an offence to conspire with or incite people to have sex with children abroad.
Home Office minister Timothy Kirkhope said: "These people defile children and bring shame on this country and the full force of the law must be used against these depraved people.
"This is an abhorrent activity. We are doing everything we can to prevent it and protect children everywhere."
Human rights campaigners are worried about "sex tourists" from advanced countries preying on children in the Third World.
The U.N. Children's Fund estimates there are at least one million child prostitutes in Asia alone with the greatest numbers in India, Thailand, Taiwan and the Philippines.
The British government has announced that it is also planning laws to prosecute sex tourists when they return home.
Australia and Germany already have laws under which their nationals can be prosecuted for offences committed by abroad.
